messageBody:
Hi Cedric,

On 2/20/07, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 2/19/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> > "Helper" is a lullaby word in OO design, like "Manager" and "Worker".
> > There's a reason why Smalltalk environments consider utility methods to
> > be a code smell.
>
> There's a reason why Smalltalk environments are dead.

Surely you didn't mean to suggest that the community's attention to
object-oriented design would've been the reason for Smalltalk
remaining a craft of few...?

And Smalltalk is not dead, by the way. Two years ago I met two
programmers in London who were getting paid to write Smalltalk. And in
two different companies.

And sarcasm aside...

On 2/20/07, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> It seems to me that helper methods/classes can be useful. I can
> certainly see why certain ways to implement them can be considered
> "smells", but it certainly doesn't make the overall concept useless.

I'm pretty sure we all agree that "helpers" as a concept isn't
useless. It's just that some of the subscribers of this list (myself
included) are of the opinion that the helpers should be realized as
first-level concepts rather than clumping a dozen functions
(functions, not methods) into a single helper class.

Lasse
